At Tue, 13 Jan 2009 15:48:09 -0800,
Gordon Mohr wrote:
>
> I don't know of a formal comparison, or of any other systems in use with
> Heritrix-centric workflows.
>
> The WARC writing of recent Heritrix releases already leverages the info
> left in the CrawlURI by the Persist[Log|Store|Load]Processor +
> FetchHistoryProcessor mechanism to write 'revisit' records instead of
> full 'response' records, when appropriate.
>
> We're using the Persist[Log|Store|Load]Processor +
> FetchHistoryProcessor mechanism on a number of production crawls at
> IA, writing WARCs. We'll continue to maintain and improve this
> approach, and the 'continuous/adaptive' functionality coming after
> 2.2 will assume WARCs as the usual content format.
>
> A recent version of BerkeleyDB added the ability for multiple
> 'environments' (disk database directories) to efficiently share the
> same cache space, so carrying-forward the data from a previous crawl
> will be easier in the future: there will be a single environment
> directory which contains just the URI dup-reduction data, which can
> be reused for future crawls. (Now, you either use a
> PersistLogProcessor log which must be imported to the new crawl's
> 'state' environment, or use the PersistStoreProcessor and share
> forward the whole 'state' environment, which is bloated with other
> unnecessary info.)

Hi Gordon -

Many thanks for your response. I have been making use of the
PersistLogProcessors and will be trying out recrawling soon. Thanks
also for the information regarding the BerkeleyDB improvements. Most
likely we will continue to use the log format which, being a single
file and easily transferred between machines seems more appropriate to
our circumstances here.

Apologies for not responding sooner.

-Erik

--Multipart_Wed_Jan_21_14:09:04_2009-1
